title: An Unconventional Monaural Hearing Aid Fitting
chief_complaint: I am a very active runner and triathlete, but I have a very difficult time localizing sound and orienting myself to my surroundings. I also have trouble recognizing speech in noise and hearing anyone on my left side.

problem_summary.onset: Sudden hearing loss in the left ear occurred approximately 8 years ago.
problem_summary.course: Hearing decreased significantly with an episode of vertigo (resolved after 2 days). Hearing has been stable since. Constant tinnitus in the left ear began 1 year ago.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: History of vertigo (resolved); constant tinnitus in the left ear.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Inability to localize sound or orient to surroundings, specifically during triathlons; difficulty hearing speech on the left side.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Primary goal is sound awareness and ability to localize sound for safety during sports.

history.present_illness: Patient reports sudden hearing loss in left ear 8 years ago with vertigo. Vertigo resolved, but hearing did not recover. Tinnitus started 1 year ago.
history.otologic_history: MRI 8 years ago was negative for retrocochlear pathology.
history.prior_management: No medical intervention or amplification since onset.
history.patient_goals: Improve localization and awareness for triathlons.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Normal hearing in the right ear (250-8000 Hz). Gradually sloping moderately-severe to severe SNHL in the left ear.

numeric_results.Left_AC_Thresholds: Sloping from ~60 dB HL at 250 Hz to ~90 dB HL at 8000 Hz

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Normal speech recognition in right ear. Moderately-severe SRT loss in left ear with very poor word recognition ability.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Right ipsi/contra normal. Left ipsi/contra present at 500/1000 Hz but absent at 2000/4000 Hz. Decay negative.

history.present_illness: Hearing Aid Evaluation (HAE) visit, 2 weeks post-evaluation.
history.patient_goals: Patient prioritized sound awareness and localization over sound quality/distortion. Needs device for triathlons.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: Discussed CROS, BiCROS, BAHA, SoundBite, and monaural amplification. Patient chose monaural amplification for the poorer (left) ear despite poor WRS, to aid localization.

history.present_illness: Hearing Aid Fitting visit, 2 weeks post-HAE.
history.prior_management: Fitted with Phonak Naida S CRT V with power receiver and custom c-shell mold.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: Real Ear Measures (REM) matched NAL-NL1 targets. LDLs measured to ensure output did not exceed discomfort levels. Directional microphones verified in test box.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with normal hearing in the right ear and a moderately-severe to severe sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear. Word recognition is excellent in the right ear (100%) but very poor in the left ear (38%), suggesting significant distortion. Despite the poor speech clarity in the left ear, the patient elected for monaural amplification in that ear to restore localization cues and environmental awareness.
counseling_points: Because your word recognition score in the left ear is 38%, the hearing aid will provide sound awareness but speech may still sound distorted.
Fitting the poorer ear is unconventional, but it is the only option that restores the ability to localize sound, which is your primary goal for triathlons.
We have applied a moisture-resistant coating and provided a drying kit to protect the aid during exercise.
If the sound becomes uncomfortable or if the distortion is too distracting, we can discuss CROS options which route sound to your better ear.
notes_for_actor: You are an active triathlete concerned about safety because you can't tell where sounds are coming from.
You are not looking for perfect speech clarity; you just want to know 'where' things are.
You are willing to accept distortion in the bad ear if it helps you orient yourself.
You experienced vertigo 8 years ago but are fine now.
